DataElement.preferredName: AIDS-Related Kaposi Sarcoma Systemic Illness Stage
DataElement.preferredDefinition: Term to describe the disease stage for an individual with AIDS-related Kaposi's sarcoma, using the AIDS Clinical Trials group staging classification to evaluate the degree of Immunosuppression present based on CD4 cell count.

DataElementConcept.preferredName: AIDS-Related Kaposi Sarcoma Systemic Illness Extent
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: information relating to the immune system and the staging (the extent of a cancer within the body, especially whether the disease has spread from the original site to other parts of the body) of Kaposi Sarcoma (a malignant neoplasm characterized by a vascular proliferation which usually contains blunt endothelial cells)._(sis-TEM-ik) The most aggressive form of Kaposi sarcoma.  It presents in patients who are infected with the human immunodeficiency virus.  It can affect the skin and internal organs._Affecting the entire body._Of low value or worth._The state of the organism when it functions optimally without evidence of disease._The range, magnitude, or distance over which a thing spans an interval of distance, space, or time.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: The most aggressive form of Kaposi sarcoma.  It presents in patients who are infected with the human immunodeficiency virus.  It can affect the skin and internal organs.

Concepts.definition: The most aggressive form of Kaposi sarcoma. It presents in patients who are infected with the human immunodeficiency virus. It can affect the skin and internal organs.

Property.preferredDefinition: (sis-TEM-ik) Affecting the entire body.:Of low value or worth.:The state of the organism when it functions optimally without evidence of disease.:The range, magnitude, or distance over which a thing spans an interval of distance, space, or time.

Concepts.definition: Refers to a person's state of physical, mental and social well-being; usually it refers specifically to the state of being in good health, a state of complete physical, mental and social well-being, and does not consist only of the absence of disease or infirmity. In any organism health constitutes a form of homeostasis with inputs and outputs of energy and mass in approximate equilibrium allowing for growth and continued survival. In humans, a subjective feeling of well-being coming from somatic and cognitive perceptions is considered an essential component of health.
The range, magnitude, or distance over which a thing spans an interval of distance, space, or time.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: the process of identifying a disease by the signs and symptoms (NCI Glossary).

Refers to a person's state of physical, mental and social well-being; usually it refers specifically to the state of being in good health, a state of complete physical, mental and social well-being, and does not consist only of the absence of disease or infirmity. In any organism health constitutes a form of homeostasis with inputs and outputs of energy and mass in approximate equilibrium allowing for growth and continued survival. In humans, a subjective feeling of well-being coming from somatic and cognitive perceptions is considered an essential component of health.
